key_insight: Dynamic Rebatching (DREX) reorganizes running inference work so tokens/requests that become ready to exit are regrouped into new batches, preserving early-exit benefits while keeping hardware-efficient batch processing.
problem_solved: Standard batching forces all requests to wait for the slowest item or forces premature exits, which either wastes compute or degrades output quality for Early-Exit LLMs.
method: Continuously monitor per-token/request early-exit readiness as inference progresses through layers.
Dynamically form homogeneous sub-batches of items that are ready to take an early exit and schedule them immediately, instead of waiting for the entire original batch.
Use an adaptive scheduler/policy to balance latency, throughput, and quality (integrates with existing runtimes to maintain hardware utilization).
impact: Enables lower latency and higher effective throughput for early-exit LLMs without sacrificing output quality, making EE architectures more practical in production inference pipelines.
visual_elements: Flow diagram: token/request lifecycle showing monitoring → dynamic regrouping → early exit vs continued processing

paper_title: Dynamic Rebatching for Efficient Early-Exit Inference with DREX
paper_authors: Xuting Liu, Daniel Alexander, Siva Kesava Reddy Kakarla, Behnaz Arzani, Vincent Liu
